summary.para: When the same test is run multiple times within the same context, such as one TeamCity build, this env var would be set to a nonempty alphanumeric string for all runs except the default run.
Examples: InTest self-rerun of failed tests, Perforator multiple executions.
The idea is that every run should be able to make unique paths for its short-named resources, such as logs and dumps, without conflicting when uploading results to TC or overwriting on disk.
The default run should have no suffix, so that regular runs of tests, or single runs of InTests, had clear names for their files.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.TestFixtureLifetime
member.summary: This lifetime terminates when the test fixture's TestFixtureTearDown executes. The guard is NOT applied to its termination.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.TestLifetime
member.summary: This lifetime terminates when the test's TearDown executes. Each test (test case) has its own lifetime. If your test is STA, this lifetime will be terminated under .

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.FailTestIfCheckFails
member.summary:
Whatever the family of methods ExecuteWithGold will throw exceptions on gold mismatch.
If you are set this property to false you must to react to gold mismatch in any of the following ways: * Override OnDataDifferentFromGoldFile method for custom handling * Make use of return value of ExecuteWithGold methods

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.SupportMultipleGolds
member.summary:
Changes mode of reporting exceptions from ExecuteWithGold family of methods.
When enabled,an exception will not be thrown on first gold mismatch, but will be logged with LogLevel.ERROR. If anything logged with Error level in Tests, it is considered as error in TearDown and the test fail. Test will run to the end and you can update all golds without obligation to run test for each gold file.
It should be considered as default for tests multiple golds

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.UnitTestFixtureTempFolder
member.summary: Use the folder as a root folder for all temporary data created in unit tests to make clean-up easier. This folder is re-created / cleaned up per test FIXTURE, not per test or test case.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.SetUpInternal(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime)
member.summary: A safer alternative to overriding (and not forgetting to call the base). You will be called during the setup sequence, and you'll get a lifetime which terminates on teardown sequence. The call is not guarded, and the lifetime termination is not guarded either (unlike ). Basically, you are free to use either of the lifetimes, just note that one has guarded termination, and their termination actions won't interweave (all will terminate first, then ).

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.TraceCategories
member.summary: List of namespaces that will be with LogLevel = Trace during the execution of the test.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.RollbackSetUpAndThrow(System.Exception)
member.summary: Call when your overridden SetUp method fails with an exception (and is about to cancel executing the test and calling its TearDown). Since we have consistency checks that base setups/teardowns are called correctly, without this call you will get an assertion when running the next test that prev TearDown hasn't been called (and any set up activities were not rolled back). The exception will be rethrown, potentially as a nested exception, and any logger-recorded exceptions would add to it.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell.RelativeTestDataPath

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.Build.UnitTestDegreeOfParallelism
member.summary: Determines how many NUnit processes can be spawned in parallel. The default is 1. Format: 1, 2, 3 — explicit number of max parallel processes. Format: x1, x2, x.5 — a factor of the machine processor count.
The entry method, runs all tests, async.

Enums subplatform DLLs, prepares for realizing subplatform stuff on disk to run tests on it. Done once before running any dll of the subplatform. Should be cheap to call even if nothing is tested for this sub, because all the real work (like making a folder) is delayed until smb triggers the lazy workdir.
The most specific method: per-subplatform, per single parameters run, and per single DLL in the subplatform. Finally, checks if there're filters excluding this DLL, and if not, runs it.
Per subplatform, per the set of parameters for single run . Runs all DLLs of the subplatform.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.Build.UnitTestingTasks.UnitTestingExtractedFileConflicts.IgnoreFilePathRegex
member.summary: Defines the regex for relative file paths (in the extraction folder) of the files whose conflicts are to be ignored upon extraction.

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.Categories.ManualExecutionAttribute
member.summary: Marks test with predefined category.
member.remarks:
By default there is no any special local settings for this category, so such tests will run among others.
If you wouldn't like to see these tests in local test-runs do the following:
1. Open ReSharper Settings
2. Go To 'Unit Testing'
3. Add '__ManualExecution__' into 'Skip tests from categories'

summary.para: Adds a temporary high-priority layer which intercepts all of the writes.
It has no availability condition, so it will be available with every binding with the highest priority — for reading values in features.
For writing, if you do the default Smart binding, the default smart-write strategy will cause the value to sink to the per-machine layer, and such a write won't be temporary.
To do a temporary write that will be revoked upon termination, use (or do ).
The settings store bound to an application-wide context, with writes restricted to the temporary layer only.
Reads would go as if in context, which now includes the temp layer. In environments with Project Model, this includes Solution settings.
The live context is bound for the lifetime of this component.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Components.PartCatalogsForTests.CreateMasterBinderIsolatedOnAssembliesAndRefAsm(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell,System.Reflection.Assembly[])
member.summary: Creates a binder suitable for loading stuff from the given assemblies, assuming their layout on disk. Assemblies available for resolve: 1) Any assemblies in the same folders as the given assemblies. 2) Any assemblies from RefAsm nuget of the currently used version. This MUST NOT depend on the environment of the current machine. The set of DLLs in the dir might be a bit leaky in the local scenario (as we do not have Shell here yet to make a strict set), but on the server only involved nupkgs are extarcted.

member.summary: The base impl. Default NUnit behavior for attributes' application has a problem that any exceptions cause the test to be silently ignored. Such tests just disappear from CI runs without registering a failure. A solution is to turn exceptions into test failures. The base class implements this behavior.

member.summary: Lazy-loader of the requested package.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.JetNuGet.INuGetLazyDataPackage.LocallyExpandedDir
member.summary: Directory into which all package files are expanded, under their raw part paths (not the effective paths) — so you'll have to look for lib/Net/file.dll or DotFiles/file.dll rather than just file.dll. The root will have the extra file, package file itself.

summary.para: Treats the test data directory which could have some of its files taken out to NuGet.
With non-intest, the files are expected to be in the test data directory, so the NuGet has to be retrieved and the files extracted to the test data directory.
By convention, such act of replacing SCC files with a NuGet is marked with the TestData.Nuspec file, which also tells the exact ID and Version of the NuGet package — from the spec.
The NuGet package is to be extracted AS IS into the directory which has the TestData.Nuspec file.
Also by convention, the nuget files are in the TestData.Generated.Dir subfolder (this way they're invisible to SCC).
This allows the nuget to be easily replacable with the local files, say, for debug.

When the test is being authored, place the test data and golds in the TestData.Generated.Dir subfolder. When ready, create a TestData.Nuspec, upload the package, and delete the files — the test should work just as before, now via nuget. To debug the test, edit the files it extracts, and then update the nuspec version and upload the new package when done. Don't forget to delete the files and check.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.JetNuGet.NuGetTestDataHelper.TestDataNuspecRestore_Spec_WriteCmd(JetBrains.Util.FileSystemPath)
member.summary: Write the helper batch file which allows to upload the updated package

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.JetNuGet.NuGetTestDataHelper.FindNuGetConfigForTest(JetBrains.TestFramework.BaseTestNoShell)
member.summary: For a test, looks up a nuget config file to be used for nuget packages in the test. Searches NuGet.Config in the test data directory and its parents, up to (exclusively) the Product Home Dir. The first met (closest to the test data dir) file wins, no combining with uppers for predictability (because server tests might use different sparse checkout and missing an upper file would introduce subtle bugs). Does not consider the Product Home Dir itself, because the file in it is for build-time nugets (dotnet-build feed) and not test-time nugets (dotnet-test-data feed). Does not consider any directories above homedir for obvious reasons. Does not consider per-user or machine-wide settings, for tests must not depend on environment.

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.MappedTestPaths
member.summary: Cleans up test data of unique environment-specific paths, by replacing them with semantic nicknames which can be stored in the gold files.
member.remarks: This is a former aggregate of which has been taken out to a separate class because it's used in isolated spots, and a lot of code in the base test class has been scaring off non-PSI-tests folks which would like to use it in their very simple tests. This also included InTests. So it's now in a separate file, but its lifecycle has only gotten simpler.

Such tests just disappear from CI runs without registering a failure. A solution is to turn exceptions into test failures. The base class implements this behavior.

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCaseSourceWithData.TestCaseSourceWithDataAttribute
member.summary: TestCaseSourceWithDataAttribute merges functionality of TestCaseSource and TestCase attributes. It can be useful if you want to add some const parameters to TestCaseSource or just merge (cartesian product) two or more TestCaseSource. But not all features of TestCaseSource are supported. In fact you can provide case sources only in one way: pass the type that: 1. Has default constructor 2. Implements ITestCaseDataProvider (see TestCaseDataSingleParameter and TestCaseDataManyParameters)

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCompiler.TestTargetFramework.NetFramework481
member.summary:
End of Microsoft support: ????-??-??.

Particular qualities:
ARM64 support.
Use COR_PROFILER_PATH environment variable for ARM64.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCompiler.TestTargetFramework.NetCore10
member.summary:
End of Microsoft support: 2019-06-27.
Particular qualities:
Support CORECLR_PROFILER_PATH_32 / CORECLR_PROFILER_PATH_64 environment variables for specific 32-bit and 64-bit processes. The CORECLR_PROFILER_PATH environment variable is obsolete.
CoreCLR has its own copy of environment variables for managed code on Unix. Use SetEnvironmentVariableW export in libcoreclr.so / libcoreclr.dylib to modify it.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCompiler.TestTargetFramework.NetCore30
member.summary:
End of Microsoft support: 2020-03-03.
Inherits all features from
Particular qualities:
Support attach with https://github.com/dotnet/diagnostics.
No SetEnvironmentVariableW export. The dirty hack was implemented on Unix. We are parsing ELF / Mach-O files for getting symbols from libcoreclr.so / libcoreclr.dylib.
is inconsistent with ICorProfilerInfo3::GetRuntimeInformation(). They return 3.0.0 and 4.0.30319 respectively. Has ICorProfilerInfo10 for detection since 3.0.0-preview6. See https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/PROF-857 and https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/22845 for details.
Attach implemented in 3.0.0-preview4, but was completely redesigned in 3.0.0-preview6 and 3.0.0-preview7. Use ICorProfilerInfo10 for detection. See https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/PROF-893, https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/PROF-874 and https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/16796

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCompiler.TestTargetFramework.NetCore31
member.summary:
End of Microsoft support: 2022-12-13.
Inherits all features from
Particular qualities:
No SetEnvironmentVariableW export. Use ICorProfilerInfo11 on Unix for fixing. See https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/pull/27512 fro details.
is inconsistent with ICorProfilerInfo3::GetRuntimeInformation(). They return 3.1.0 and 4.0.30319 respectively. Has ICorProfilerInfo11 for detection since 3.1.0-preview3. See https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/PROF-857 and https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues/22845 for details.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestCompiler.TestTargetFramework.Net50
member.summary:
End of Microsoft support: 2022-05-08.
Inherits all features from
Particular qualities:
.NET macOS x64+Rosetta2 is supported on macOS ARM64.

member.summary: Must be in the namespace which contains all the tests needing the shell. This class creates the test environment before running tests in the namespaces under it, and destroys it after all the tests.

member.summary: Override in assemblies which would like to use assemblies redirection for product assemblies. Emulates behavior in VS. Useful for testing with plugins. The default value correlates with .

member.summary: Override in assemblies which would like to perform one time initialization. One time initialization includes installing bundled plugins and etc. The default is False.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly`1.IsRunningTestsInInternalMode
member.summary: Override in assemblies which would like to run tests in internal mode. The default is False.

member.name: P:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly`1.IsRunningTestsWithAsyncBehaviorProhibited
member.summary: Override in assemblies which would like to run tests with suppressed async calls like or . The default is False.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly.RunningEnvironment
member.summary: Can be used in base test only (in this assembly), and, well, in derived classes also.

summary.para: Accumulates logger exceptions.
Throw them out when noone is to intercept them so that they got right to NUnit (eg in test teardown).
Must be turned off and nulled when the test-environment-assembly shuts down, otherwise it might interfere with running other tests.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly.IsPendingLoggedExceptions
member.summary: Gets whether there were recorded exception (except gold difference) while running the shelled test, and they were not yet thrown out into the test runner

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly.ThrowLoggedExceptions
member.summary: If the host is currently running, and there were exceptions trapped during within its run, throws these exceptions out.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.TestEnvironmentAssembly.WaitForStartedTestShell
member.summary: After the setup has been completed (and before its teardown), waits for the actual Shell to start up and be ready as a component container, unless in the Async Prohibited mode (in which case it must be ready immediately).

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DebuggingStreamWriter.CreateDebuggingOrDirectStreamWriter(System.IO.MemoryStream,System.Text.Encoding,System.Collections.Immutable.ImmutableArray{JetBrains.Util.FileSystemPath})

summary.para: Supports debugger stepping over the gold/tmp test data files. Place a breakpoint in the gold/tmp file, and debugger would break when that line is dumped by the test.
Of course, does not work so good if test dumps a lot of lines as a single string.
Only when debugger is attached from start! Skips if unattached, for speed and safety.

member.param: The output stream into which the text writer would be writing without a debugger.
Encoding, for text writer on the target stream.
A list of files in which breakpoints might be placed. Would automatically try gold/tmp couterparts for any given paths; skips NULLs and empties.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DebuggingStreamWriter.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Override for optimization. Otherwise it ends up in string->char[]->char, but that would be slower.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DebuggingStreamWriter.Write(System.Char[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Override for optimization. Otherwise it ends up in char[]->char, but that would be slower.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DebuggingStreamWriter.Write(System.Char)
member.summary: Write(Char) is the dead-end method for TextWriter, all over un-overridden come down to it, so we must handle it

member.summary: We step on golds and temps, for user's choice. Depending on the helper used, might get any of two defined. So try flipping the extension either way.

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DebuggingStreamWriter.DebugStepper
member.summary: Adds debugger stepping support to an arbitrary text file. Call with a line number to signal debugger we're stepping into the file.
member.remarks: The idea is borrowed from the build file debugger stepper built into MSBuild. We emit MSIL code which is marked with debugger source line info in such a way that it points to text file lines.

member.name: T:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff
member.summary:
This Class implements the Difference Algorithm published in "An O(ND) Difference Algorithm and its Variations" by Eugene Myers Algorithmica Vol. 1 No. 2, 1986, p 251.
There are many C, Java, Lisp implementations public available but they all seem to come from the same source (diffutils) that is under the (unfree) GNU public License and cannot be reused as a sourcecode for a commercial application. There are very old C implementations that use other (worse) algorithms. Microsoft also published sourcecode of a diff-tool (windiff) that uses some tree data. Also, a direct transfer from a C source to C# is not easy because there is a lot of pointer arithmetic in the typical C solutions and i need a managed solution. These are the reasons why I implemented the original published algorithm from the scratch and make it avaliable without the GNU license limitations. I do not need a high performance diff tool because it is used only sometimes. I will do some performace tweaking when needed.
The algorithm itself is comparing 2 arrays of numbers so when comparing 2 text documents each line is converted into a (hash) number. See DiffText().
Some chages to the original algorithm: The original algorithm was described using a recursive approach and comparing zero indexed arrays. Extracting sub-arrays and rejoining them is very performance and memory intensive so the same (readonly) data arrays are passed arround together with their lower and upper bounds. This circumstance makes the LCS and SMS functions more complicate. I added some code to the LCS function to get a fast response on sub-arrays that are identical, completely deleted or inserted.
The result from a comparisation is stored in 2 arrays that flag for modified (deleted or inserted) lines in the 2 data arrays. These bits are then analysed to produce a array of Item objects.
Further possible optimizations: (first rule: don't do it; second: don't do it yet) The arrays DataA and DataB are passed as parameters, but are never changed after the creation so they can be members of the class to avoid the paramter overhead. In SMS is a lot of boundary arithmetic in the for-D and for-k loops that can be done by increment and decrement of local variables. The DownVector and UpVector arrays are alywas created and destroyed each time the SMS gets called. It is possible to reuse tehm when transfering them to members of the class. See TODO: hints.
diff.cs: A port of the algorythm to C# Copyright (c) by Matthias Hertel, http://www.mathertel.de This work is licensed under a BSD style license. See http://www.mathertel.de/License.aspx
Changes: 2002.09.20 There was a "hang" in some situations. Now I undestand a little bit more of the SMS algorithm. There have been overlapping boxes; that where analyzed partial differently. One return-point is enough. A assertion was added in CreateDiffs when in debug-mode, that counts the number of equal (no modified) lines in both arrays. They must be identical.
2003.02.07 Out of bounds error in the Up/Down vector arrays in some situations. The two vetors are now accessed using different offsets that are adjusted using the start k-Line. A test case is added.
2006.03.05 Some documentation and a direct Diff entry point.
2006.03.08 Refactored the API to static methods on the Diff class to make usage simpler. 2006.03.10 using the standard Debug class for self-test now. compile with: csc /target:exe /out:diffTest.exe /d:DEBUG /d:TRACE /d:SELFTEST Diff.cs 2007.01.06 license agreement changed to a BSD style license. 2007.06.03 added the Optimize method. 2007.09.23 UpVector and DownVector optimization by Jan Stoklasa (). 2008.05.31 Adjusted the testing code that failed because of the Optimize method (not a bug in the diff algorithm). 2008.10.08 Fixing a test case and adding a new test case.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.DiffText(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Find the difference in 2 texts, comparing by textlines.
member.param: A-version of the text (usualy the old one)
B-version of the text (usualy the new one)
member.returns: Returns a array of Items that describe the differences.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.DiffText(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find the difference in 2 text documents, comparing by textlines. The algorithm itself is comparing 2 arrays of numbers so when comparing 2 text documents each line is converted into a (hash) number. This hash-value is computed by storing all textlines into a common hashtable so i can find dublicates in there, and generating a new number each time a new textline is inserted.
member.param: A-version of the text (usualy the old one)
B-version of the text (usualy the new one)
When set to true, all leading and trailing whitespace characters are stripped out before the comparation is done.
When set to true, all whitespace characters are converted to a single space character before the comparation is done.
When set to true, all characters are converted to their lowercase equivivalence before the comparation is done.
member.returns: Returns a array of Items that describe the differences.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.Optimize(JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DiffData)
member.summary: If a sequence of modified lines starts with a line that contains the same content as the line that appends the changes, the difference sequence is modified so that the appended line and not the starting line is marked as modified. This leads to more readable diff sequences when comparing text files.
member.param: A Diff data buffer containing the identified changes.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.DiffInt(System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Find the difference in 2 arrays of integers.
member.param: A-version of the numbers (usualy the old one)
B-version of the numbers (usualy the new one)
member.returns: Returns a array of Items that describe the differences.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.DiffCodes(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Int32},System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This function converts all textlines of the text into unique numbers for every unique textline so further work can work only with simple numbers.
member.param: the input text
This extern initialized hashtable is used for storing all ever used textlines.
ignore leading and trailing space characters

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.SMS(JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DiffData,System.Int32,System.Int32,JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DiffData,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: This is the algorithm to find the Shortest Middle Snake (SMS).
member.param: sequence A
lower bound of the actual range in DataA
upper bound of the actual range in DataA (exclusive)
sequence B
lower bound of the actual range in DataB
upper bound of the actual range in DataB (exclusive)
a vector for the (0,0) to (x,y) search. Passed as a parameter for speed reasons.
a vector for the (u,v) to (N,M) search. Passed as a parameter for speed reasons.
member.returns: a MiddleSnakeData record containing x,y and u,v

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.LineByLineDiff.LCS(JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DiffData,System.Int32,System.Int32,JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.DiffData,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: This is the divide-and-conquer implementation of the longes common-subsequence (LCS) algorithm. The published algorithm passes recursively parts of the A and B sequences. To avoid copying these arrays the lower and upper bounds are passed while the sequences stay constant.
member.param: sequence A
lower bound of the actual range in DataA
upper bound of the actual range in DataA (exclusive)
sequence B
lower bound of the actual range in DataB
upper bound of the actual range in DataB (exclusive)
a vector for the (0,0) to (x,y) search. Passed as a parameter for speed reasons.
a vector for the (u,v) to (N,M) search. Passed as a parameter for speed reasons.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.TestRandom.NextChildren(System.Nullable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Gets new randomly-initialized random objects (e.g. if you want to run several random processes in parallel and want them all to be deterministic no matter what).

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.TestRandom.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a random number within a specified range.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to minValue and less than maxValue; that is, the range of return values includes minValue but not maxValue. If minValue equals maxValue, minValue is returned.
member.param: The inclusive lower bound of the random number returned.
The exclusive upper bound of the random number returned. maxValue must be greater than or equal to minValue.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.TestRandom.Next(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a nonnegative random number less than the specified maximum.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero, and less than maxValue; that is, the range of return values includes zero but not maxValue.
member.param: The exclusive upper bound of the random number to be generated. maxValue must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: M:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.TestRandom.Next01
member.summary: Returns a random floating-point value in the [0..1) range.

member.name: F:JetBrains.TestFramework.Utils.TestUtil.myLastDetectedTestDataPathBase
member.summary: Per-assembly test data detection based on attrs and sub-platforms. No need to keep more than one cached because assembly tests are always run contiguously.
